title: Verified Purchase
content: Let me begin with the answer to a direct question: is this book better than KILLERS OF THE FLOWER MOON?  Yes, and by a wide margin.  This is a historical tale that draws on the powers of fictional narrative.  First and foremost, the story must be true.  Hence, the success of the story rises or falls on the quality of the historical incidents themselves, because the resulting story will directly affect the elements of the narrative that are essentially novelistic: characters, themes, setting and plot.  The story of the Wager satisfies each of those elements.  In other words, David Grann chose wisely.  And such choices are always guesses, to some degree.  Once the commitment is made to sift through mountains of documents and other evidentiary material, the die has been cast: the resulting story could be a crashing bore; key questions might never yield satisfactory answers; plot lines could end in blind alleys; themes could prove to be maudlin commonplaces, and so on.  Not in this case.  We have an array of fascinating characters, a great adventure story, a novelistic plot, a riveting setting and a sobering set of lessons learned.

title: Verified Purchase
content: I purchased the book as a backup for other books in my reviewing queue that were about to ship.  After being disappointed by KILLERS OF THE FLOWER MOON, but seeing the hype for THE WAGER, I decided to read it until more interesting books arrived.  However, once I started to read it I simply could not stop.  Only one small quibble: the book ends with what the author (SPOILER alert) considers a reflection on the evils of empire.  In other words, a dash of seasoning from the Woke shaker.  Ultimately, the story is relevant for our own times and our own preoccupation with colonizers/colonized/oppressors/oppressed, etc.  It is worthwhile to point out that every thinking writer in the 18th century (especially the putatively most ‘conservative’ ones, Johnson and Burke) were opposed to the aspirations of empire, particularly as they involved self-interested motives.  The book is being described as Master and Commander meets Lord of the Flies.  Fair enough, but the brief, third act brings everything down to the seedy world of politics.  The book does not end on some high, moral, virtue-signaling ground, but in the world that is simply all too familiar.  Bishop Sheen said he gave up on politics after Pontius Pilate.  Amen.  That does not undercut the impact of the story.  It simply reinforces the usefulness of James Ellroy’s category of ‘tragic realism’ and, in this case, the manner in which politics can dilute actions of heavily-compromised courage and determination and render them (publicly) mundane.

title: A tale of futility, extremely well told
content: I'll admit that I was not particularly pleased when my book group determined to read this title, but a title I would have preferred had already been strongly resisted by another member, and I had no real objection, so I determined to get on with reading it. If nothing else, it would expose me to David Grann's writing style, which I would see quite a bit more of when I eventually get around to Killers of the Flower Moon, which has been on my TBR list for a while now. Getting into this account of an 18th century shipwreck of which I'd never heard quickly proved much more engaging than I had dared to imagine, and if the period's events, politics and people are of any interest, The Wager is well worth the time spent reading it. The doomed vessel was one of a fleet sent by the British Navy in hopes of capturing a Spanish treasure ship and avenging an injury to a British captain. The mission would involve making the dangerous passage around Cape Horn to the Pacific, and the Wager was not alone of its company in failing to reach the other ocean.

content: A notable element of tracing these events is how many of those involved, from the ship's captain down to a pair of midshipmen, wrote contemporaneous logs or journals of the voyage. Additionally, several accounts, from divergent perspectives, were published as various groups of survivors made it back to England. So the modern historian has an abundance of contemporary sources on which to draw, and Grann has clearly familiarised himself with most, if not all of them.  And he recounts the events of the court martial convened to determine the degree of responsibility to be assigned to the various survivors in the face of their conflicting accounts. Finally, he invites the reader to see these events in the light of history and what were the results.

title: Verified Purchase
content: The Wager was an English ship that set sail from England in 1740 during an imperial war with Spain. It was the mid-1700s, and navigational tools were primitive. Diseases among the seafarers spread rapidly, and I was incredulous, realizing how little they knew about curbing nutritional deficiencies such as scurvy. It seems absurd that in addition to not knowing about the necessity for vitamin C, insufficient levels of niacin were causing psychosis and night blindness resulting from lack of Vitamin A. After shipwrecking on a desolate island off the coast of Patagonia, the story is as much about human nature as it is about surviving on an island and attaining its mission against the Spanish. It is fascinating to read about how they discovered new food sources and what they chose to learn and ignore from natives whose cultures had thrived in the areas where the Englishmen became castaways. If they were going to continue to survive and continue their naval mission, they had to build new boats without the technology available in their homeland, and there were myriad disagreements about how to proceed and also about which path to follow when it was time to embark on the dangerous waters again. Disharmony leads some groups to set sail in opposite directions eventually. When the survivors arrived back in England, the accounts of what happened were not in sync.

title: A Page Turner
content: Author David Grann recounts a seafaring adventure like non other from the mid 1700’s. I loved the preposterous idea of the whole British expedition to locate and capture a treasure ship on the other side of the world in an era of basic navigation by the seat of the pants! The British scheme to hijack and capture a Spanish galleon is to be carried out by a squadron of five British warships. One of these ships, HMS The Wager, is under the command of Captain Cheap who revels in the idea that he will have battles befitting his desire to become a war hero. When the flotilla departs Britain, they are hounded across the Atlantic by warships under Don Jose Pizarro of Spain. After typhus strikes the crew and they finally reach neutral Brazil for a respite, the fleet continues south to Cape Horn despite continued disease, scurvy and malcontent among the sailors. Disaster strikes south of the Horn, separating the ships, leaving The Wager alone, damaged and essentially unable to sail, off the coast of southern Chile. When the weathered ship finally is blown into rocks off an uninhabited coastal island, she is abandoned, raided of her stores, lifeboats, weapons and gunpowder. The fragmented survivors set up camps for each faction on the island and try to survive on limpets and seaweed as summer ends and the cold Chilean winter sweeps in from the Antarctic south. What ensues is an adult real-life version of Golding’s “Lord of the Flies”, leading to near mutiny, death, starvation and feuding that eventually sends the few survivors off in tiny makeshift boats in different directions. Captain Cheap and his remaining followers headed North toward Chiloe Island governed by the Spanish. Meanwhile, the Gunner, Bulkeley and a larger group head south to weather Magellan’s Strait in hopes of reaching England. The few survivors who do make it back to Britain then must convince the Admiralty and public that they are not mutineers and subject to justice by being swung from a yardarm. The book is a masterful piece of British Naval history, and well worth the read for anyone interested in the human ability to survive under the most horrendous of conditions at sea.

title: Verified Purchase
content: On January 28, 1742, a thing that could very loosely have been called a boat - more like boat-ish, washed up on the shore of Brazil. On it were about thirty barely living men who had once been part of the crew of the British ship called The Wager that had left England in 1740 as part of a small fleet off to harass the Spanish in the so-called "War of Jenkin's Ear" or the War of Austrian Succession. They seemed to be all that was left of a crew of a couple of hundred, and they told the story of their wreck off the southern tip of South America, their survival on the desolate landscape for months, and their incredible 3000-mile-long voyage to Brazil. But, wait, there's more! Six months later an even sadder boat washed up on the coast of Chile, with just three inhabitants, including the ship's captain, and they added a new layer to the tale:  murder and mutiny.  When the survivors finally arrived back home in England, having been away from their loved ones for 4 or 5 years, accusations flew back and forth, various accounts were published, and the public was enthralled by the mystery and drama of what exactly had happened to The Wager and its crew.

title: A Sea Saga: Mutiny, Myth or a Dash of Both?
content: David Grann, an award winner non-fiction author, has done his best to tease out the facts of the history of the British vessel, the Wager.  Britain was at war with Spain. In 1740, the re-fitted merchant ship, Wager, joined a fleet setting out to capture a Spanish galleon loaded with treasure. The galleon had been sighted off the coast of Patagonia. Many on the Wager were enlisted naval men, but most were "pressed" into service and were of questionable character.  On route, typhus killed the Captain and many of the original crew.  Other sailors succumbed to scurvy.  A young, inexperienced Captain, David Cheap was put in command of the Wager.  Severe storms in the Strait of Magellan in addition to faulty navigation techniques, caused the Wager to shipwreck on a desolate island. There were sailors, who could not swim and they drowned in their attempts to swim ashore.

title: A great read.
content: I just finished reading the book the "Island of the Blue Foxes" which is a tale of the Bering expedition from Siberia to Alaska.  One of two ships the St. Peter gets marooned on what is today known as Bering island off the coast of Kamchatka.  The stories are extremely similar in terms of how the hierarchical order on the ship was abandoned in the society created on land. What's more amazing is that the stories involve literally the same year 1741 and 1742.  Instead of being shipwrecked in Patagonia, this group is shipwrecked in the Artic!  Both groups take the remnants of the former ship and create a new boat which takes them to safety. title: Utterly Fascinating
content: The Wager is a gut-wrenching story. The living conditions aboard the ship are terrible. The storms in that latitude are incessant. The crew is ravaged by disease, and the reader becomes inured to casual death. The ship’s young captain, through no fault of his own, misses the best season to round Cape Horn but is obliged to try, since his commanding officer has apparently succeeded, albeit in a larger, safer, and better crewed vessel. Critically, accurate navigation is impossible due to the inability, at that time, to accurately calculate longitude. The fact that the ship is wrecked is in the subtitle so it’s not a spoiler. But what happens after that is, well, the reason the book is selling better than, say, Endurance or Resolute. Whatever the phrase “against all odds” means, this book redefines it to the most improbable extreme. The outcome of the court martial in the final pages is so unexpected it might have come out of a novel. The Wager is a thrill to read but it may give you nightmares. If it doesn’t, try sailing around Cape Horn yourself in the wrong season.

title: Verified Purchase
content: What is intensely interesting in Grann’s telling is how a warship in 1742 was fitted and the number of bodies needed to keep it afloat. The Wager had a crew of just over 250, but it was not unusual that larger ships needed well over 500. Not soon after departing Southampton the crew began to die off from Scurvy. The Wager then was caught in a violent storm after going around the cape still determined to chase Spanish treasure… the ship was pushed and wedged between two rocks onto a desolate island off the coast of Patagonia. The surviving crew became castaways… and enemies in separate groups, primarily pointing fingers at the ship’s captain's incompetence. Survival was nearly impossible; then came desperate ideas of their fate causing a mutiny… leading to several attempts to sail back to the UK all the while trying to avoid becoming Spanish prisoners. Amazingly, several groups did over several years get back to tell their stories. From these various published versions David Grann has woven his increasable tale of the sea and survival.

title: A very well written and researched true adventure.a
content: I like stories of the sea and have myself crewed on a tall ship.  I can only imagine the conditions under which the men in these stories must have experienced.  There are three or more groups that develop once the Wager wrecks -- the Captain and his followers, the Gunner and his, and some miscreants who didn't follow either.  They each try to escape their solitude of the shipwreck with sickness and hunger, and most of the major book characters actually make it back to England eventually.  Many of them tell conflicting stories or write popular books about their experiences.  The English Naval courts find the whole matter troubling, and basically let everyone off.  I expected dramatic court proceedings that would clarify, in my mind, who were the real heroes of this book.  In the end, all were victims of an imperialistic government that sent such men to their doom so many times on ill-fated expeditions.  It is a tribute to human endurance, and the skill and fortitude of British seamen, that a fraction of those that set out actually survived with a story to tell, embellished as necessary to save their careers and their necks.
